awd_titl_txt: CC* Regional: Integrating the Colorado Western Slope Research and Education (R&E) Community into the National R&E Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
High-speed, reliable networking infrastructure is vital to an organization's ability to thrive in today's rapidly evolving scientific and technical environments. Such network connectivity is essential for success in business, science, communication, global collaboration, education, and outreach. The network connectivity in the Western Slope Rocky Mountain region of Colorado is challenged. This project will bring together research and education (R&E) stakeholders to identify specific areas of need, work with public and private partners to identify infrastructure and other network resources, define the scope of the network to be constructed, and design a network. Stakeholders benefit from gaining knowledge of available resources for better network connectivity, building relationships with the regional and national network providers, technical training, and access to high-performance network connectivity. Project goals include ensuring underserved populations from rural areas of Colorado and Northern New Mexico have a diverse, well-educated workforce and that students are offered the highest caliber educational opportunities and resources. Improved network access supports economic development and growth, increased diversity, and development and expansion of employment opportunities.

The project team identifies and documents network resources and provides a network design that addresses feasibility, costs, and deployment of the network. The team performs site visits to identify, document, and assess network paths, and one-time and recurring costs. Regular meetings with stakeholders and vendors are conducted. A workshop is planned to teach stakeholders about advanced network tools and technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rocky Mountain states are often regarded as ?geographically challenged,? given their vast spaces with low population density and varied natural geography that includes mountains, deserts, and rocky terrain. Colorado is one example. The state?s Front Range benefits from dense populations where broadband providers and fiber optic infrastructure are prevalent and affordable. Rural communities on Colorado?s Western Slope, however, have low population density, substantial geographic dividers and challenges, and limited broadband Internet options that are considerably more expensive. A primary goal of this project was to develop a plan to enhance digital equity and access for Colorado communities west of the continental divide.

At the successful completion of this planning grant, a team from the Front Range GigaPoP (FRGP) delivered a plan to establish cost-effective, high-speed and highly available broadband for Research and Education (R&E) organizations on Colorado?s Western Slope. When executed, the plan will ensure these entities have the bandwidth essential for successful scientific investigation, global collaboration, education and outreach at costs similar to the Front Range. This involved working with Western Slope research and education stakeholders to identify existing network infrastructure assets and areas of opportunity, partnership, and collaboration. The team also built relationships and developed partnerships with regional broadband initiatives in Western Colorado, and explored possibilities for collaboration and cooperation between these regional networks. The resulting cyberinfrastructure design will also help enable underserved populations in rural Colorado to maintain and grow a diverse, well-educated workforce and will ensure the region?s students are offered the highest caliber educational opportunities and resources. Details of the plan were presented in a funding proposal submitted by the team under NSF 23-526.

Relationships and partnerships with leaders active in community networking in Western Colorado were established, and discussions continue regarding partnerships between these organizations and the FRGP.  These entities include: The Colorado Broadband Office; Colorado Mesa University; Project Thor and the Northwest Colorado Council of Governments (NWCCOG); Region 10; Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory (RMBL); University of Colorado at Boulder;  Utah Department of Transportation (UDOT); Utah Education and Telehealth Network (UETN); and Western Colorado University. 

Similarly, potential partnerships with other entities and active projects and in the region were investigated, including: Arcadian Infracom; Colorado Department of Transportation; Delta- Montrose Electric Association (DMEA); Lumen; Navajo Technical University (NTU);  Tri-State Generation and Transmission Association; Utah Education and Telehealth Network (UETN); and Western States Pact Broadband Group; and the Southwest Higher Education Knowledge and Technology Exchange (SHEKATE).

Many research and education networks (RENs) have policies that preclude them from delivering services to commercial entities, e.g. local Internet Service Providers (ISPs). The FRGP team developed a plan for implementing and managing virtual routing that enforces FRGP policies while delivering R&E network services on hardware owned and operated by regional broadband organizations. If successful, this plan could be adopted by other RENs, allowing them to extend access to R&E resources to eligible entities in local communities, such as school districts, libraries and museums.
